90000.title: Creating Circular Materials, Compatible with Life
90000.summary: A compilation of leading industry resources to guide healthy, non-toxic material use in buildings
90000.problem: Circular building policies are diverse in form and efficiency across industries and fields; leading to different goals, outcomes and approaches
90000.solution: Project compiles three best resources to homogenise circular material creation in different partners
90000.outcome: Healthy material use in buildings in a similar manner across several stakeholders
90000.additional_info: Brightworks Sustainability in Portland (HQ) has compiled a comprehensive guide on creating circular materials that are compatible with life. This compilation includes leading industry resources to promote healthy, non-toxic material use in buildings. The project aims to homogenize circular material creation among different partners by compiling three of the best resources. By promoting healthy material use in buildings across various stakeholders, Brightworks Sustainability is working towards a more sustainable and environmentally friendly future.

framework_elements.name: Team up to create joint value

90000.tags: Circular construction; circular materials; material use

90010.title: Product take-back models in use in the commercial and real estate sector
90010.summary: Altering building fit-outs strategies to accomodate for circularity.
90010.problem: Utility buildings periodically fit-out replacable/degrading appliances and fixtures which is costly resource-wise
90010.solution: Strategy describes models to change fit-out handling; implementing circular principles and adding a loop to fit-out elements
90010.outcome: Circular fit-outs prevent waste streams and increases lifespan of fit-out materials across sectors
90010.additional_info: CBRE Dallas (HQ) is implementing product take-back models in the commercial and real estate sector to alter building fit-outs strategies and accommodate circularity. This strategy involves periodically replacing degrading appliances and fixtures in utility buildings, which can be costly resource-wise. By implementing circular principles and adding a loop to fit-out elements, CBRE is able to prevent waste streams and increase the lifespan of fit-out materials across sectors.

90020.title: You can’t improve what you don’t measure - Responsible operational waste management
90020.summary: Using LEED Zero, A programme by USGBC, to achieve zero waste in Petinelli HQ, Brazil
90020.problem: Measurement of circular practices and sustainable energy sources often remains limited to a select few parameters
90020.solution: The project managers opted to measure every possible way of retaining materials and energy sources to maximise every possible gain
90020.outcome: The resulting office space is net zero; using solar power but also retained rainwater, combining waste reduction strategies and living laboratory practices
90020.additional_info: You can’t improve what you don’t measure - Responsible operational waste management using LEED Zero, a programme by USGBC, to achieve zero waste in Petinelli HQ, Brazil. Measurement of circular practices and sustainable energy sources often remains limited to a select few parameters. The project managers opted to measure every possible way of retaining materials and energy sources to maximise every possible gain. The resulting office space is net zero; using solar power but also retained rainwater, combining waste reduction strategies and living laboratory practices.
90020.tags: Net zero office building; circular practices; sustainable energy
90020.location: R. Rockefeller, 500 - Rebouças, Curitiba - PR, 80230-130, Brazil

90030.title: Making the case for Clean Construction: Mexico City
90030.summary: As part of the C40 Clean Construction accelerator plan, outlining the pathways for a middle american metropole
90030.problem: Clean Construction requires advancements in distinct both policy and infrastructure
90030.solution: Project aims to bolster three distinct areas: network of suppliers and receivers, a virtual inventory and asset management program and physical laydown space
90030.outcome: Building on the SF project conclusions, the project will allow policymakers and builders to synthesise new solutions effortlessly
90030.additional_info: Making the case for Clean Construction in Mexico City as part of the C40 Clean Construction accelerator plan, outlining pathways for a middle American metropole. Clean Construction requires advancements in both policy and infrastructure, aiming to bolster a network of suppliers and receivers, a virtual inventory and asset management program, and physical laydown space. Building on the SF project conclusions, this project will allow policymakers and builders in Mexico City to synthesize new solutions effortlessly.

framework_elements.name: Team up to create joint value

90030.tags: Roadmap; circular cityplanning; C40 clean construction

90040.title:
Arden Precinct - circular economy embedded into 
masterplanning and building design
90040.summary: Taking circular economy into account from prototyping onwards at the planning level.
90040.problem: The recent prevalence of CE as a concept means it is often lagging behind development on a cityplanning level
90040.solution: Thinking in circularity at the earliest/highest level of city planning
90040.outcome: The precinct contains circular thinking and CE principles not only in its planning but also in its buildings, new construction designs, and upkeeping
90040.additional_info: Arden Precinct, located at 173 Laurens St in North Melbourne VIC, is a prime example of circular economy principles being embedded into masterplanning and building design. From prototyping onwards, the precinct incorporates circular thinking at the highest level of city planning. This forward-thinking approach ensures that not only the planning process, but also the buildings, new construction designs, and upkeep within the precinct align with circular economy principles. Despite the recent prevalence of circular economy as a concept, Arden Precinct sets a new standard for integrating these principles into urban development. Powered by WSP Global, the precinct serves as a model for sustainable and innovative city planning.
90040.location: 173 Laurens St, North Melbourne VIC 3051, Australia

90050.title: A City's Leadership to Unlock Full Circularity Potential - San Francisco
90050.summary: Comprehensive circularity strategies in an American city.
90050.problem: San Francisco is to be a net zero carbon city in 2040
90050.solution: Similarly to Mexico City; using C40 principles to bolster three areas: network of suppliers and receivers, a virtual inventory and asset management program and physical laydown space
90050.outcome: Culminating in full city development, but primarily established an Innovation Center to aid research into circularity in SF and serving as an example of modular, reusable building (temporary)
90050.additional_info: San Francisco's Environment Department is leading the way in implementing comprehensive circularity strategies to unlock the city's full potential. By following the C40 principles and aiming to be a net zero carbon city by 2040, San Francisco is focusing on building a network of suppliers and receivers, implementing a virtual inventory and asset management program, and creating physical laydown space. The city has also established an Innovation Center to conduct research on circularity and showcase examples of modular, reusable building practices. This initiative is not only driving full city development but also serving as a model for other cities looking to embrace circularity.

framework_elements.name: Team up to create joint value

90050.tags: Net zero cities; Circular cityplanning; roadmap; C40 clean construction

90060.title: Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park
90060.summary:
Long-term project for the unused Olympic Stadium and
its surrounding area; concerning asset reuse, disposal, optimisation and looping
90060.problem: Specialised building projects require adequate, bespoke dismantling while taking into account circular building principles
90060.solution: Firm inherited responsibility for the reuse, disposal, optimisation and looping of the remaining assets
90060.outcome: LLDC has achieved the repurposing and reusal of most of the original dwelling buildings while also deconstructing the stadium without creating excessive waste streams
90060.additional_info: Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park is a long-term project managed by the London Legacy Development Corporation (LLDC) in GXVM+HW London. The project involves the reuse, disposal, optimisation, and looping of assets in the unused Olympic Stadium and its surrounding area. Specialised building projects are required for adequate dismantling while considering circular building principles. The LLDC has successfully repurposed and reused most of the original dwelling buildings and deconstructed the stadium without creating excessive waste streams, showcasing their commitment to sustainable development.
90060.source2: EMF Circularity in the Built Environment p15: https://emf.thirdlight.com/link/bpso50t2ia56-9bw2n5/@/preview/1?o

90070.title: Construction Reuse Platform: Bexleyheath
90070.summary: Effects of implementing a reuse and refurbishment platform, combined with space repurposing and social justice
90070.problem: Local initiatives for reuse and refurbishment fail to fulfil secondary functions
90070.solution: Comprehensive policy to estabilish a communal reuse platform which also doubles as space repurposement
90070.outcome: Has resulted in greater reuse, less vacant space in the Bexleyheath town
90070.additional_info: Construction Reuse Platform in Bexleyheath, implemented by Keepmoat Ltd and Globechain, has had a significant impact. By combining reuse and refurbishment with space repurposing and social justice initiatives, the platform has successfully reduced vacant space in the town. This comprehensive policy has established a communal reuse platform that fulfills secondary functions, unlike previous local initiatives.

90160.additional_info: Wood in Construction: Building requirements set for a district in Helsinki mandate the usage of massive wood for building and facade. 90250.title: Asphalt recycling
90250.summary: All public works with asphalt are to reuse old material in construction and/or renovation of public infrastructure
90250.solution: Part of Circular Ljubljana; old material is used as backfill, added quantity to superstructure or lower bearing material
90250.outcome: Renewal of roads and pavements is a supposedly closed loop (unknown material mix)
90250.additional_info: Asphalt recycling is a key component of Circular Ljubljana, where all public works with asphalt in the City of Ljubljana are required to reuse old material in construction and/or renovation of public infrastructure. This practice helps in reducing infrastructure renewal material requirements by using old material as backfill, adding quantity to superstructure, or lower bearing material. The renewal of roads and pavements in Ljubljana is seen as a supposedly closed loop, although the exact material mix is unknown.

90280.title: GtoG

90290.title: Smart Lighting in Surrey

90290.problem: Surrey aims to fully optimise its street lighting
90290.solution: Skanska was selected to overhaul the lighting system; installed a dynamic system of white efficient lights
90290.outcome: Reduced energy bills, saving 60k t of carbon and 150 million kwh over 25 years. All lamps are connected and remotely reported broken to be replaced

All lamps are connected and remotely reported broken to be replaced. Surrey is leading the way in sustainable and efficient lighting solutions.

90320.title: The Recycled Houses
90320.summary: Looking back on houses made up of 90% recycled materials

90320.outcome: Evaluation of recycled building materials shows: Quality and Condition equal to trad construction after lifespan
90320.additional_info: The Recycled Houses at Carlsgade 2, 5000 Odense, Denmark are a testament to the durability of using 80-90% recycled materials in construction. A 30-year evaluation has shown that these apartment buildings, constructed using traditional methods, have maintained their quality and condition equal to that of buildings made with new materials. Looking back on these houses, it is clear that recycled materials can be just as durable as new materials.

90330.title:
84 Harrington street in Capetown, South Africa, 
named world's tallest hemp built building
90330.problem: The construction sector is projected to exceed its carbon budget by 2026 using current construction practices.
90330.solution: Using hemp as basis for building materials removes some of the emissions from production of traditional selections
90330.outcome: Reduced construction + lifespan footprint; hemp is 100% natural, CO absorbing, energy saving, very lightweight and durable
90330.additional_info: 84 Harrington Street in Capetown, South Africa, named world's tallest hemp-built building, showcasing hemp-based building. The construction sector is projected to exceed its carbon budget by 2026 using current construction practices. Using hemp as a basis for building materials removes some of the emissions from the production of traditional selections, resulting in reduced construction and lifespan footprint. Hemp is 100% natural, CO absorbing, energy-saving, very lightweight, and durable. Hemporium and Afrimat Hemp are located at 84 Harrington St, District 6, Capetown, 7925, South Africa.
90330.location: 84 Harrington St, District 6, Capetown, 7925, South Africa

90340.title:
Quay Quarter Tower, Sydney Australia - Setting 
a global benchmark for adaptive reuse
90340.summary: Design of a net-positive (or at LEAST net-zero) building using old structure
90340.problem: Demolition of large buildings often removes options for better practices
90340.solution: Project retains 66% of existing columns/slabs, 95% of internal walls of old structure
90340.outcome: The reuse of materials resulted in a total carbon saving of over 7,500 tonnes, an estimated economic savings of $130 million and an estimated construction time saving of 12 months
90340.additional_info: Quay Quarter Tower in Sydney, Australia is setting a global benchmark for adaptive reuse by designing a net-positive (or at least net-zero) building using the old structure. The project retained 66% of existing columns/slabs and 95% of internal walls, resulting in a total carbon saving of over 7,500 tonnes. This reuse of materials also led to an estimated economic savings of $130 million and a construction time saving of 12 months. The demolition of large buildings often removes options for better practices, but Quay Quarter Tower demonstrates the benefits of adaptive reuse. The project was carried out by AMP Capital and VinZero at 50 Bridge St, Sydney NSW 2000, Australia.
90340.tags: Net zero building; structure reuse; circular demolition

90350.title:
JP Morgan Chase HQ - New York City's first all-electric, 
circular and net-zero skyscraper
90350.summary: As part of the Midtown rezoning plan for NY, use of state of the art technology in office spaces
90350.problem: Midtown Rezoning aims to alleviate the non-green rigid spaces
90350.solution: Skyscraper is net-zero carbon and completely electrically powered, circular and extremely efficient
90350.outcome: A building integrated into space: supports greenery and transport infrastructure through its formfactor while also providing positive environmental influences
90350.additional_info: JP Morgan Chase HQ, located at 270 Park Ave in New York City, is the first all-electric, circular, and net-zero skyscraper in the city. This innovative building is a result of the Midtown rezoning plan, which aims to incorporate state-of-the-art technology into office spaces to create more environmentally friendly and efficient buildings. The skyscraper is completely electrically powered and net-zero carbon, making it extremely efficient. Additionally, the building is designed to support greenery and transport infrastructure through its form factor, providing positive environmental influences. Designed by Foster + Partners, this building is a prime example of sustainable architecture in the heart of New York City.
90350.tags: Circular cityplanning; rezoning; net zero building; space
90350.location: 270 Park Ave, New York, NY 10017, United States

90360.title:
Burwood Brickworks Shopping Centre, Australia, an 
industry leading sustainable retail design and 
construction
90360.summary: Building using Greensheet, a living document adapting to construction
90360.problem: Avoiding demolition requires awareness and appropriate likelihood of alternatives
90360.solution: Greensheet functions as a dynamic material passport; was employed in the refitting and reuse of a shopping centre
90360.outcome: Greensheet is a publicly available tool because of this research; Shopping Centre is a certified living building for net positive impact
90360.additional_info: Burwood Brickworks Shopping Centre in Australia is an industry-leading sustainable retail design and construction project that utilized Greensheet, a living document that adapts to construction processes. By avoiding demolition and promoting awareness of alternative options, Greensheet was able to function as a dynamic material passport in the refitting and reuse of the shopping centre. This publicly available tool was a key component in the Shopping Centre's certification as a living building with a net positive impact. Located at 70 Middleborough Rd, Burwood East VIC 3151, Australia, the project was a collaboration with the Green Building Council of Australia (GBCA).
90360.location: 70 Middleborough Rd, Burwood East VIC 3151, Australia

90370.title: Canada's largest heritage rehabilitation project
90370.summary: Reusing materials in cultural heritage to upgrade lifespan and quality
90370.problem: Cultural heritage in the built environment presents a complex case weighing retention and modernisation against each other
90370.solution: 100-year old parliament building undergoing renovation, attempting to improve while retaining conservational value
90370.outcome: Mostly reuse and reconstruction of original steel; cost efficient and saving up to 120 tonnes of emissions
90370.additional_info: Canada's largest heritage rehabilitation project at 111 Wellington St, Ottawa, ON K1A 0A6, is reusing materials in cultural heritage to upgrade lifespan and quality. The 100-year old parliament building is undergoing renovation, attempting to improve while retaining conservational value. The project involves mostly reuse and reconstruction of original steel, making it cost efficient and saving up to 120 tonnes of emissions. Cultural heritage in the built environment presents a complex case weighing retention and modernisation against each other, with WSP Global leading the way in this innovative project.
90370.location: 111 Wellington St, Ottawa, ON K1A 0A6, Canada

90380.title:
Pyörre House, Finland - the first Finnish building
designed and constructed to test the EU’s
design criteria for adaptability, disassembly and
recyclability
90380.summary: Evaluation of relevant EU criteria and tools at every stage of building process to ascertain validity
90380.problem: EU design criteria had been untested up to this point in time
90380.solution: Project built an entire house according to the new principles outlined in the EU design criteria
90380.outcome: Project created has a carbon handprint as big as its carbon footprint
90380.additional_info: Pyörre House in Finland is the first building in the country designed and constructed to test the EU's criteria for adaptability, disassembly, and recyclability. Throughout the building process, relevant EU criteria and tools were evaluated to ensure validity, as these criteria had not been tested previously. The project resulted in the construction of an entire house based on the new principles outlined in the EU design criteria. However, it is important to note that the project's carbon handprint is as significant as its carbon footprint. The project was carried out in collaboration with FinlandGBC in Lohja.
90380.tags: EU design criteria; net zero building

90390.title:
Apple Park - A campus to promote creativity, 
innovation and wellbeing
90390.solution: Project revamped the Silicon Valley-based flagship campus for Apple Inc.
90390.outcome: LEED Platinum campus; single building uses precast concrete for efficiency purposes
90390.additional_info: Apple Park, located at 1 Apple Park Wy in Cupertino, CA 95014, is a sustainable campus designed by Foster + Partners to promote creativity, innovation, and wellbeing. The project revamped the Silicon Valley-based flagship campus for Apple Inc., resulting in a LEED Platinum campus where a single building uses precast concrete for efficiency purposes.
90390.location: 1 Apple Park Wy, Cupertino, CA 95014, United States

90400.title: La Borda social housing complex in Barcelona
90400.summary:
Social and Environmental Justice as part of circular 
construction
90400.problem: The added local social value of high quality/cost circular building is debatable
90400.solution: Government initiative to apply good practices to social housing in the crowded Barcelona city
90400.outcome: Cooperative communal decisionmaking ensured the desired measures were taken, such as less underground cosntruction and biobased efficiency
90400.additional_info: La Borda social housing complex in Barcelona, located at Carrer de la Constitució, 85, 89, 08014 Barcelona, Spain, exemplifies Social and Environmental Justice as part of circular construction. The added local social value of high quality/cost circular building is debatable, but the government initiative to apply good practices to social housing in the crowded Barcelona city has been successful. Cooperative communal decision-making ensured the desired measures were taken, such as less underground construction and biobased efficiency. The project aligns with the goals of C40 to promote sustainable and inclusive urban development.

framework_elements.name: Team up to create joint value

90400.tags: Climate justice; social housing; circular cityplanning
90400.location: Carrer de la Constitució, 85, 89, 08014 Barcelona, Spain

90410.title: Park 20|20
90410.summary:
Office building park serving as a material bank as well as 
profitable estate business opportunity
90410.problem: There is a need to adapt economic valutations to contain residual, circular value
90410.solution: New park with office buildings constructed for large fims near Amsterdam, designed to give flexible real estate opportunities and be a material bank for its lifespan
90410.outcome: Increased value by residual value and component valuation, lease price advantage through reduction in service costs
90410.additional_info: Park 20|20 is an office building park near Amsterdam, designed by William McDonough + Partners. It serves as a material bank and profitable estate business opportunity, with a focus on adapting economic valuations to contain residual, circular value. The new park offers flexible real estate opportunities for large firms, with increased value achieved through residual value and component valuation. The lease price advantage is further enhanced by a reduction in service costs. Located at Monoceros, 2132 LS Hoofddorp, Park 20|20 is a unique development that combines sustainability with economic viability.

framework_elements.name: Team up to create joint value

90410.tags: Office park; material bank; circular economy
90410.source2: WBCSD The Business Case for Circular Building p21: https://www.wbcsd.org/Programs/Cities-and-Mobility/Sustainable-Cities/Transforming-the-Built-Environment/Resources/The-business-case-for-circular-buildings-Exploring-the-economic-environmental-and-social-value

90420.title: The Resource Rows and Upcycle Studio
90420.summary: Circular approaches strongly incorporating locality of materials
90420.problem: How is circular value creation managed and implemented?
90420.solution: Project aims to make use of locality; reusing old brick facades and building materials from abandoned local buildings
90420.outcome: Up to 45% reduction in emissions by reuse of materials and installation of reused products
90420.additional_info: The Resource Rows and Upcycle Studio at NREP Southamptongade 4, Oerestad, 2150 Copenhagen, Denmark, are implementing circular approaches that strongly incorporate the locality of materials. The project aims to make use of locality by reusing old brick facades and building materials from abandoned local buildings. This approach not only reduces emissions by up to 45% through the reuse of materials and installation of reused products but also effectively manages and implements circular value creation.
90420.source2: WBCSD The Business Case for Circular Building p24: https://www.wbcsd.org/Programs/Cities-and-Mobility/Sustainable-Cities/Transforming-the-Built-Environment/Resources/The-business-case-for-circular-buildings-Exploring-the-economic-environmental-and-social-value

90430.title: Watts Works
90430.problem: The construction sector is projected to exceed its carbon budget by 2026 using current construction practices.
90430.solution: 58 shipping containers form a 4 story apartment complex in LA, each container is 100% recycled, with total product waste only 15% of comparable buildings
90430.outcome: 100% recycled materials with no waste going to landfill
90430.additional_info: Watts Works Container based building at 9502 Compton Ave, Los Angeles, CA 90002, United States is revolutionizing the construction sector. The 4 story apartment complex, made from 58 shipping containers, is not only innovative but also environmentally friendly. With each container being 100% recycled, the total product waste is only 15% of comparable buildings. This sustainable approach ensures that no waste goes to landfill, helping to combat the construction sector's projected carbon budget exceedance by 2026. Developed by Daylight Community Development and Decro Corporation, Watts Works is leading the way in eco-friendly construction practices.
90430.location: 9502 Compton Ave, Los Angeles, CA 90002, United States
90430.source2: WBCSD The Business Case for Circular Building p27: https://www.wbcsd.org/Programs/Cities-and-Mobility/Sustainable-Cities/Transforming-the-Built-Environment/Resources/The-business-case-for-circular-buildings-Exploring-the-economic-environmental-and-social-value

90440.title: Exchange House
90440.problem: Utility buildings periodically fit-out replacable/degrading appliances and fixtures which is costly resource-wise
90440.solution: Project includes exemplary reuse of materials with multi-level collaboration
90440.outcome: Potentially solves the fit-out problem by providing office refurbishment materials to communities and building projects
90440.additional_info: Exchange House is a mixed-use building with circular fit-outs, where utility buildings periodically replace degrading appliances and fixtures. This project includes exemplary reuse of materials with multi-level collaboration, potentially solving the fit-out problem by providing office refurbishment materials to communities and building projects. British Land and Globechain are involved in this initiative located at 12 Primrose St, London EC2A 2EG, UK.

framework_elements.name: Team up to create joint value

90440.source2: WBCSD The Business Case for Circular Building p29: https://www.wbcsd.org/Programs/Cities-and-Mobility/Sustainable-Cities/Transforming-the-Built-Environment/Resources/The-business-case-for-circular-buildings-Exploring-the-economic-environmental-and-social-value

90450.title: Rehafutur Engineer's House
90450.summary: Bio-based renovation of a historical building in Europe.
90450.problem: Renewable isolation effectiveness is relatively unproven
90450.solution: Using fully recycled insulation, a historical building is given new life
90450.outcome: A list of challenges in the report; primarily there needs to be valuation of cost savings because of new isolation
90450.additional_info: Rehafutur Engineer's House in CQVQ+44 Loos-en-Gohelle, France undergoes bio-based renovation, using fully recycled insulation to give new life to a historical building. Despite challenges such as the relatively unproven effectiveness of renewable isolation, the report highlights the need for valuation of cost savings due to the new isolation techniques.
90450.source2: EMF Circularity in the Built Environment p9: https://emf.thirdlight.com/link/bpso50t2ia56-9bw2n5/@/preview/1?o

90460.title: Brummen Town Hall
90460.summary: Modular, reconstructible design on top of a 1890 foundation
90460.problem: Concerns about shifting borders required a modular, shorter lifespan building
90460.solution: Incorporating material passport tech to function as depot after lifespan
90460.outcome: Qualities of historic building are intact, while approximately 90% of materials can be dismantled and reused when the borders inevitably shift
90460.additional_info: Brummen Town Hall, located at Engelenburgerlaan 31, 6971 BV Brummen, features a modular and reconstructible design built on top of a 1890 foundation. The building was constructed with concerns about shifting borders in mind, resulting in a shorter lifespan. However, by incorporating material passport technology, the building can function as a depot after its lifespan is complete. This innovative approach allows approximately 90% of the materials to be dismantled and reused when the borders inevitably shift, while still maintaining the qualities of the historic building. The project was carried out by Brummen Municipality in collaboration with Turntoo.
90460.source2: EMF Circularity in the Built Environment p22: https://emf.thirdlight.com/link/bpso50t2ia56-9bw2n5/@/preview/1?o

90470.title: Liander head office
90470.summary:
Using materials from existing cluster of 
structures while building sophisticated new large office building
90470.problem: Redeveloping in a circular way on the same land as an existing cluster of buildings
90470.solution: Mainly the reuse of scrapwood is interesting, but in total more than 80% of the original cluster's materials were reused
90470.outcome: A portable, modular canopy of sorts was created. Challenges overcome included fire safety and ensuring quality construction with second generation materials
90470.additional_info: Liander head office, located at Dijkgraaf 4, 6921 RL Duiven, was built using materials from an existing cluster of structures in a circular redevelopment on the same land. More than 80% of the original cluster's materials were reused, with a focus on scrapwood. A portable, modular canopy was created, overcoming challenges such as fire safety and ensuring quality construction with second generation materials. The project was a collaboration between Liander, Turntoo, and Alliander.
90470.source2: EMF Circularity in the Built Environment p26: https://emf.thirdlight.com/link/bpso50t2ia56-9bw2n5/@/preview/1?o

90480.title: Resource Efficient house
90480.summary: Modular building using structural insulated panels (SIP)
90480.problem: Many buildings drain the environment for their entire lifespan
90480.additional_info: Resource Efficient house Modular building using structural insulated panels (SIP) achieves net zero emissions and follows a cradle-to-cradle scope. Located at 190 Cathedral St, Glasgow G4 0RF, United Kingdom, this building is a prime example of sustainable construction practices, aiming to minimize environmental impact and reduce waste. Zero Waste Scotland is proud to support this innovative project.
90480.tags: Modular building; net zero building; cradle-to-cradle
90480.location: 190 Cathedral St, Glasgow G4 0RF, United Kingdom
90480.source2: EMF Circularity in the Built Environment p31: https://emf.thirdlight.com/link/bpso50t2ia56-9bw2n5/@/preview/1?o

90490.title: Judicial Police Compound
90490.summary:
Building process included sourcing and implementing a 
sustainable flooring solution
90490.solution: The compound had to be designed according to strong design principles to reach verification; this includes modular, durable and sustainable reqs
90490.outcome: Zero construction waste in process, natural ventilation, bespoke flooring solution with low impact
90490.additional_info: The Judicial Police Compound at 5 Bd de l'Hautil, 95300 Pontoise, France was built with a strong focus on sustainability and high quality. The building process included sourcing and implementing a bespoke flooring solution that met sustainable requirements. The compound was designed according to strong design principles to reach verification, including modular, durable, and sustainable features. Zero construction waste was produced during the process, and natural ventilation was incorporated into the design. The Ministere de l'Interieur and Groupe 6 were involved in the construction of this environmentally friendly and high-quality building.
90490.tags: Sustainable flooring; French high quality building;
90490.source2: EMF Circularity in the Built Environment p42: https://emf.thirdlight.com/link/bpso50t2ia56-9bw2n5/@/preview/1?o

90500.title: White Collar Factory
90500.summary: Sustainable solutions of a mixed use building
90500.solution: Long list of implementations for sustainability, also including smart services
90500.outcome: LEED PLatinum building; occupational emissions are at least 25% lower than usual
90500.additional_info: White Collar Factory at 1 Old Street Yard, London EC1Y 8AF, United Kingdom is a sustainable mixed-use building designed by Arup. The challenges of designing for longevity were met with a long list of sustainable solutions, including smart services. This LEED Platinum building has occupational emissions that are at least 25% lower than usual.
90500.tags: LEED platinum; mixed use sustainable building; smart services
90500.location: 1 Old Street Yard, London EC1Y 8AF, United Kingdom
90500.source2: Arup Circularity in Built Environment p27: https://www.arup.com/perspectives/publications/research/section/circular-economy-in-the-built-environment

90510.title: Sky Believe in Better building
90510.summary: Arup designed modular and prefabicated building
90510.solution: Project is fully timber constructed, using modular prefab elements to accomodate replacement systems
90510.additional_info: Sky Group's Believe in Better building in Osterley, Isleworth, Greater London TW7, UK was designed by Arup and is fully timber constructed. The project utilizes modular and prefabricated elements to accommodate replacement systems, making it a deemed passive house with net zero energy consumption.

90510.location: Osterley, Isleworth, Isleworth, Greater London TW7, UK

90520.title: SolarLeaf
90520.solution: Generates renewable energy from solar heat and algal biomass integration in an integrated building services system
90520.outcome: All gathered energy is used in a closed loop system to the energy management centre, excess heat can also be managed or for secondary heating purposes
90520.additional_info: SolarLeaf is a bio-reactive building facade developed by Arup at Am Inselpark 17 in Hamburg, Germany. It uses alternative material input and generates renewable energy from solar heat and algal biomass integration in an integrated building services system. All gathered energy is used in a closed loop system to the energy management centre, and excess heat can also be managed or used for secondary heating purposes.
90520.tags: Bio-based building; energy efficiency; renewable energy building; self sufficiency
90520.source2: Arup Circularity in Built Environment p39: https://www.arup.com/perspectives/publications/research/section/circular-economy-in-the-built-environment

90530.title: New House for London
90530.summary: Prefabricated mixed-use buildings that can operate off-grid on direct current energy networks like tiny houses
90530.solution: Prefab design for adaptable mixed-use spaces with independent (off-grid) energy system
90530.outcome: Ultimately, a low-cost solution to housing shortages affordability challenges, but requires strong circular movement to be implemented
90530.additional_info: New House for London: Arup, located at 80 Charlotte St, London W1T 4QS, UK, is developing prefabricated mixed-use buildings that can operate off-grid on direct current energy networks, similar to tiny houses. This innovative design applies circular economy principles in London, offering adaptable mixed-use spaces with independent energy systems. Ultimately, this low-cost solution aims to address housing shortages and affordability challenges, but will require a strong circular movement to be successfully implemented.
90530.tags: Prefab; circular economy; off grid energy; implementation
90530.source2: Arup Circularity in Built Environment p49: https://www.arup.com/perspectives/publications/research/section/circular-economy-in-the-built-environment

90540.title: The ReGen Villages
90540.solution: Visionary model detached from reality: Circular communities which are fully self-sufficient
90540.additional_info: The ReGen Villages in Aarhus present a visionary model of circular communities detached from reality, fully self-sufficient and in need of a feasibility assessment.
90540.source2: Arup Circular Econonmy in Built Environment p57: https://www.arup.com/perspectives/publications/research/section/circular-economy-in-the-built-environment

90550.title: Kristian Augusts Gate 13
90550.summary: First building in Norway to reach nearly 80% reused construction materials, cutting GHG emissions by 70%
90550.problem: The construction sector is projected to exceed its carbon budget by 2026 using current construction practices.
90550.solution: Pilot project: Cutting construction GHG emission by 70%, the industry has followed the example set by gate 13 using heritage building materials and donor buildings
90550.outcome: Outlines experiences in circular construction in Norway; collected in a report
90550.additional_info: Kristian Augusts Gate 13 in Oslo, Norway is the first building in the country to reach nearly 80% reused construction materials, cutting greenhouse gas emissions by 70%. This pilot project has set an example for the construction industry, which is projected to exceed its carbon budget by 2026 using current practices. The industry has started following the lead of Gate 13 by using heritage building materials and donor buildings to reduce emissions. Experiences in circular construction in Norway have been outlined in a report, with the goal of creating a more sustainable future for the industry. Futurebuilt is located at Kristian Augusts gate, 130164 Oslo, Norway.
90550.source2: SOTA & Best Practices: State of the art knowledge and best circular practices

90560.title: Ruseløkka school
90560.summary: Pilot for 2nd generation concrete use and integrated circular design
90560.problem: There exists a lack of incorporated environmental construction strategies
90560.solution: Pilot aiming for net zero (Passive house standard): use of 2nd generation low carbon concrete and integrated photovoltaics/green roofs
90560.outcome: Pilot for certain technologies; collected experiences available similar to gate 13
90560.additional_info: Ruseløkka school is a pilot project for 2nd generation concrete use and integrated circular design, aiming for net zero energy consumption. The project addresses the lack of incorporated environmental construction strategies by utilizing low carbon concrete and integrated photovoltaics/green roofs. Similar to gate 13, the pilot project at Løkkeveien 15 in Oslo, Norway will provide collected experiences and serve as a model for future sustainable construction projects.
90560.tags: Pilot; concrete; circular materials; green roofs;
90560.source2: SOTA & Best Practices: State of the art knowledge and best circular practices

90570.title: Ricehouse
90570.problem: The environmental impact of common building materials needs to be diminished and might require new innovative material use
90570.solution: Ricehouse provides insulation (material/panel), subfloors, finishings and cladding systems built using rice and plant solutions
90570.outcome: Lessened material strain and emissions, innovation of new material building standards
90570.additional_info: Ricehouse is a biobased building located at Via Aosta, 420155, Milano MI, Italy, using rice waste as a sustainable building material. The environmental impact of common building materials needs to be diminished and might require new innovative material use. Ricehouse provides insulation (material/panel), subfloors, finishings, and cladding systems built using rice and plant solutions, leading to lessened material strain and emissions. This innovative approach is setting new standards for sustainable building materials.
90570.source2: SOTA & Best Practices: State of the art knowledge and best circular practices

90580.title: Hackney Depot
90580.summary: Revival of abandoned, derelict old industrial space above bus garage
90580.problem: The construction sector is projected to exceed its carbon budget by 2026 using current construction practices.
90580.solution: Project transformed abandoned bus station to shared creative space and avoided demolition of all previous construction
90580.outcome: New space retains sense of history but provides new place for creatives and the needs of the local area, and has avoided the wasteflows of demolition or reconstruction
90580.additional_info: Hackney Depot, located at 5 Sheep Ln, London E8 4QS, United Kingdom, is a revival of an abandoned, derelict old industrial space above a bus garage. The project transformed the abandoned bus station into a shared creative space, retaining a sense of history while providing a new place for creatives and meeting the needs of the local area. By avoiding demolition of all previous construction, the project has also helped to reduce wasteful practices in the construction sector, which is projected to exceed its carbon budget by 2026 using current practices. The Hackney Depot project is a successful example of sustainable development and adaptive reuse in the construction industry.

framework_elements.name: Team up to create joint value

90580.location: 5 Sheep Ln, London E8 4QS, United Kingdom
90580.source2: SOTA & Best Practices: State of the art knowledge and best circular practices

90590.title: Venlo City Hall
90590.summary: New city hall is built using cradle-to-cradle design principles, healthy material choices and design for disassembly
90590.problem: The construction sector is projected to exceed its carbon budget by 2026 using current construction practices.
90590.solution: C2C for large office: continuous material recovery (fit-outs) and reutilisation in the system
90590.outcome: Building will recoup 11.5% of investment in 40 years
90590.additional_info: Venlo City Hall, located at Hanzeplaats 1, 5912 AT Venlo, is a new building constructed using cradle-to-cradle design principles and healthy material choices. The building is designed for disassembly, with a focus on continuous material recovery and reutilization in the system. This sustainable approach is in response to the construction sector's projected carbon budget exceeding by 2026 with current practices. The city hall is expected to recoup 11.5% of its investment over 40 years, showcasing the commitment of the Municipality of Venlo to environmentally friendly construction.

90600.title: Millennium Dome water reuse
90600.summary: As part of a larger urban quest to retain more water, the O2 Arena building is fitted to retain and reuse as much water as possible
90600.problem: London, like many others, experiences rising groundwater and too much rainwater runoff
90600.solution: Dome reuses all greywater and uses roof hopper design to avoid runoff
90600.outcome: In-building recycling scheme provides 500 m3 of water daily to become greywater again. First in the UK
90600.additional_info: The Millennium Dome in London, also known as the O2 Arena, is leading the way in water reuse as part of a larger urban initiative. The building is designed to retain and reuse as much water as possible, including all greywater and rainwater runoff. With a roof hopper design to avoid runoff, the Dome is able to provide 500 m3 of recycled water daily. This innovative in-building recycling scheme is the first of its kind in the UK and is a collaboration between the New Millennium Experience Company and the City of London. Located at Peninsula Square, London SE10 0DX, UK, the Dome is setting a new standard for sustainable water management in urban environments.
90600.organisation: New Millenium Experience Company, City of London

90610.title: Energy storage at the Arena
90610.summary: Responding to energy needs in a dynamic event location; building a resilient and adaptive energy storage using EV batteries
90610.problem: Large event location stress the energy grid extremely hard for short periods
90610.solution: Using EV batteries the project has built a 3MW power storage and mixed source energy system
90610.outcome: Provides a reliable source of sustainable energy and relieves pressure on the Dutch electricity grid while contributing to it during low demand
90610.additional_info: Energy storage at the Arena on Johan Cruijff Boulevard 1, 1101 AX Amsterdam is responding to energy needs in a dynamic event location by building a resilient and adaptive energy storage system using EV batteries. The large event location stresses the energy grid extremely hard for short periods, but with the 3MW power storage and mixed source energy system using EV batteries, the project provides a reliable source of sustainable energy. This not only relieves pressure on the Dutch electricity grid but also contributes to it during low demand. The project is a collaboration between the Municipality of Amsterdam and Nissan.
90610.tags: Amsterdam Arena; EV batteries; energy efficiency

90620.title: Peoples Pavilion
90620.summary: Circular pavilion borrows from - and returns - materials to local suppliers

90620.additional_info: Peoples Pavilion Circular pavilion borrows from - and returns - materials to local suppliers. 90620.tags: Prototype; circular economy; net zero building

90630.title: LocHal
90630.summary: Tilburg transforms former rail depot into mixed-use knowledge hub
90630.problem: Vacant old railway building was set for unnecessary destruction
90630.solution: Project rescued the 1932 NS building and was key in redevelopment of large former railway space.
90630.outcome: New building is a mixed-use sharing hub with a library, study spaces and cultural destinations. Entire building refurbished driven by sustainability
90630.additional_info: LocHal Tilburg, located at Burgemeester Brokxlaan 1000, 5041 SG Tilburg, has transformed a former rail depot into a mixed-use knowledge hub. The vacant old railway building, dating back to 1932, was rescued from unnecessary destruction and has played a key role in the redevelopment of the large former railway space. The new building now serves as a mixed-use sharing hub, featuring a library, study spaces, and cultural destinations. The entire building has been refurbished with a focus on sustainability.
90630.tags: Historical; repurposement; Mixed use hub; circular cityplanning

90640.title: The Circular Building
90640.summary: The most advanced reusable building yet
90640.problem: The construction sector uses more raw material than any other in the UK, produces the most waste and is responsible for a quarter of the country's carbon.
90640.solution: Delivered prototype for a new approach to housing in which all components would be selected for their minimal levels of embodied energy
90640.outcome: Temporary building prototype was fully modular with recoverable, reusable components
90640.additional_info: The Circular Building, showcased at the London Design Festival by Arup, is the most advanced reusable building yet. This innovative prototype for a new approach to housing features all components selected for their minimal levels of embodied energy. The fully modular design includes recoverable, reusable components, aiming to reduce the construction sector's use of raw materials, waste production, and carbon emissions in the UK.

90650.title: HAUT
90650.summary: Designing and engineering the Netherlands’ tallest timber-hybrid residential building
90650.problem: The Netherlands has committed to becoming climate neutral by 2050
90650.solution: Using timber as a building material is one of the most effective ways of accelerating decarbonisation, Amsterdam is looking to build 1 in 5 residences using timber
90650.outcome: Timber-hybrid residential tower with flexible floor plans. Exemplifies bio-based highrise construction
90650.additional_info: HAUT Designing and engineering the Netherlands’ tallest timber-hybrid residential building at Korte Ouderkerkerdijk 1, 1096 AC Amsterdam. The Netherlands has committed to becoming climate neutral by 2050, and using timber as a building material is one of the most effective ways of accelerating decarbonisation. Amsterdam is looking to build 1 in 5 residences using timber, with the timber-hybrid residential tower featuring flexible floor plans exemplifying bio-based highrise construction. Designed by Lingotto and engineered by Arup.

90660.title: Gasholders London
90660.summary: How do you turn an industrial structure into a unique residential development?
90660.problem: How do you turn an industrial structure into a unique residential development?
90660.solution: Reusing Victorian 19th century ironwork frames by relocating but retaining the inherent industrial heritage of King's Cross
90660.outcome: The project is an example of the innovative re-use of industrial structures which otherwise would remain unused. In a time of increasing urbanisation, this is essential to land conservation
90660.additional_info: Gasholders London is a unique residential development that showcases the innovative re-use of industrial structures. By reusing Victorian 19th century ironwork frames and retaining the inherent industrial heritage of King's Cross, the project demonstrates the importance of land conservation in a time of increasing urbanization. Located at 1 Lewis Cubitt Square, London N1C 4BY, United Kingdom, Gasholders London is a prime example of how industrial structures can be transformed into modern living spaces. The collaboration between Argent and Arup has resulted in a one-of-a-kind development that preserves the history of the area while providing residents with a unique and stylish place to call home.
90660.location: 1 Lewis Cubitt Square, London N1C 4BY, United Kingdom

90670.title: 1 Triton Square
90670.summary: How can existing buildings combat climate change?
90670.problem: Adapting existing office spaces to modern needs and workstyles
90670.solution: Originally designed by Arup 20 years ago, the decided marginal gains approach focused on refurbisment and expansion of existing components instead of new construction
90670.outcome: Represents one of the largest examples of circular economy practices to date. Over 25.000 seperate parts replaced, 19.000 tons of carbon saved and 66% costs saved
90670.additional_info: 1 Triton Square in London NW1 3BF, UK, represents one of the largest examples of circular economy practices to date. Originally designed by Arup 20 years ago, the decided marginal gains approach focused on refurbishment and expansion of existing components instead of new construction. This approach has resulted in over 25,000 separate parts being replaced, 19,000 tons of carbon saved, and a 66% reduction in costs. How can existing buildings combat climate change? By adapting existing office spaces to modern needs and workstyles, like British Land and Arup have done with 1 Triton Square.

90680.title: Ebury Edge
90680.summary: Creating a temporary work and community space using an innovative and reusable timber system
90680.problem: The construction sector uses more raw material than any other in the UK, produces the most waste and is responsible for a quarter of the country's carbon.
90680.solution: A temporary work and community space combining affordable workspace and retail units with cafe, communal hall. Fully electric, modular, meanwhile-use until 2025
90680.outcome: Embracing the creative potential of regeneration; in advance of long-term redevelopment, bringing valuable social spaces and infrastructure for local businesses
90680.additional_info: Ebury Edge is a temporary work and community space in London, using an innovative and reusable timber system. This project aims to address the environmental impact of the construction sector, which is responsible for a quarter of the UK's carbon emissions. The space combines affordable workspace, retail units, a cafe, and a communal hall, all fully electric and modular. It will be used until 2025, providing valuable social spaces and infrastructure for local businesses. Ebury Edge is a collaboration between Westminster City Council and Arup, located at 43 Ebury Bridge Rd, London SW1W 8DX, United Kingdom.

framework_elements.name: Team up to create joint value

90680.tags: Community space; prototype; mixed use building

90690.title: Taikoo Green Ribbon

90690.solution: Artistically driven and structurally comprehensive building and integration concept
90690.outcome: Drastic shift in expectations in what buildings & the world will look like is needed for net-zero built environment. Biophilic design has potential. Generating own energy has potential. Integration with surrounding environment is needed.
90690.additional_info: Taikoo Green Ribbon: An integrated vision for a net zero building in Asia by Arup, a concept that combines artistically driven and structurally comprehensive design with a focus on generating own energy and integrating with the surrounding environment. In geographically constrained cities like Hong Kong, the challenge of achieving a net zero built environment is even greater due to the high cost of space. A drastic shift in expectations is needed for what buildings and the world will look like, with biophilic design showing potential for success.
90690.tags: Concept; community spaces; self sufficiency; circular building; bio-based building

90750.title: Brighton Waste House
90750.problem: The construction sector uses more raw material than any other in the UK, produces the most waste and is responsible for a quarter of the country's carbon.
90750.solution: The completed project house uses over 85% waste material drawn from household and construction sites, is the first to do so in EU (+UK)

90750.additional_info: Brighton Waste House, located at the University of Brighton Faculty of Arts on Grand Parade in Brighton BN2 0JY, is a groundbreaking project that investigates the concept of permanent 'Waste' Housing. The Waste House, completed in 2014, is the first of its kind in the EU and UK, utilizing over 85% waste material from household and construction sites. This project has proven the feasibility of constructing permanent housing using waste materials, without leaving a carbon footprint.

90780.title: Cross-laminated secondary timber (CLST)
90780.summary: Upcycling waste timber to retain sequestered carbon
90780.problem: Timber waste is usually chipped and downcycled
90780.solution: CLST aims to create a cascade and high value recycling scenario for timber
90780.outcome: CLST retains sequesterd carbon by timber for longer and turns a low-value material into a standardised component
90780.additional_info: Cross-laminated secondary timber (CLST) aims to create a cascade and high value recycling scenario for timber waste, upcycling it to retain sequestered carbon. Typically, timber waste is chipped and downcycled, but CLST turns this low-value material into a standardised component. By retaining sequestered carbon in the timber for longer, CLST helps to reduce carbon emissions. This innovative approach is being researched at University College London in London.
90780.tags: Wood construction; circular materials; cross laminated timber; secondary timber

90790.title: Cutting-edge technologies towards carbon-neutral concrete

90790.outcome: Carbon Capture Use and Storage projects are in varying levels of development; with some entering use in concrete facilities in 2023
90790.additional_info: Holcim, industry leader in concrete production, is utilizing cutting-edge technologies to work towards carbon-neutral concrete. This includes piloting Carbon Capture Use and Storage projects, with some expected to be implemented in concrete facilities by 2023. Cement and concrete production are significant contributors to global greenhouse gas emissions, making decarbonization efforts crucial. Holcim, based in Zug, is at the forefront of these efforts.

90800.additional_info: Sika's Roof Recycling Program in Toronto and Boston utilizes new processing equipment to recycle post-consumer vinyl roof components, converting 98% of materials into new roofing material. Roof membranes, which are typically part of waste streams ending up in landfills, are obtained by Sika for recycling. More than 98% of the material recovered is used in building second-generation roofing products under the Sika Sarnafil brand.
90800.tags: Roof recycling; vinyl recycling; waste management

90920.title: Freement

This initiative is crucial in reducing the substantial portion of global GHG emissions caused by cement and concrete usage. Seipa Group in Rome is leading the way by showing best practices and sharing experiences in sustainable construction.
90940.tags: Concrete; recycling; second generation concrete; Italy construction sector
90940.source2: SOTA & Best Practices: State of the art knowledge and best circular practices

90950.title: Ash reuse
90950.summary: Ash generated in the process of hard coal combustion is used in the construction industry
90950.solution: Obtained from precipitation from waste gases in coal combustion; "Fly ash for concrete" is used as a type 2 additive for concrete production. Also usable as binder / sealer
90950.outcome: Fly ash is an anthropogenic material with low CO2 emissions built on reusing industrial process waste, cutting-edge technology
90950.additional_info: Ash generated in the process of hard coal combustion, obtained from precipitation from waste gases, is reused in the construction industry. This fly ash, known as "Fly ash for concrete," serves as a type 2 additive for concrete production and can also be used as a binder/sealer. This innovative approach not only reduces CO2 emissions but also promotes circularity in the construction industry. Grupa Ekotech in Warsaw is at the forefront of utilizing this anthropogenic material in a sustainable manner.
90950.tags: Circular materials; ash; reuse; waste gases; fly ash
90950.source2: SOTA & Best Practices: State of the art knowledge and best circular practices

90960.title: Modular Luminaire Product Design for Amorepacific
90960.summary: Developing a modular luminaire design with a globally unique interchangeable optical lens
90960.problem: In accordance with flexible, futureproof lighting implementation there needs to be great flexibility in luminaire types
90960.solution: Innovative, sustainable and modular luminaire product line that allows full replacement of parts and easy adjustments
90960.outcome: Offering a series of different light distributions using the same luminaire body shape, needless complex diversification or rigid disposable implementation is avoided
90960.additional_info: Arup Seoul is developing a modular luminaire product design for Amorepacific that offers a globally unique interchangeable optical lens. The innovative, sustainable, and modular luminaire product line allows for full replacement of parts and easy adjustments, ensuring flexibility in luminaire types for futureproof lighting implementation. By offering a series of different light distributions using the same luminaire body shape, unnecessary complex diversification or rigid disposable implementation is avoided.

90970.title: ADPT
90970.problem: The circular economy is changing the way buildings are planned, realised, operated and recycled at the end of their life cycle
90970.solution: Partnering with design startup, ADPT is an adaptable, flexible, scalable, reversible and transportable building system
90970.outcome: First prototype was shown off in Essen, Germany in shapes of renewable and recyclable materials which are now in use as residential or campus modules
90970.additional_info: ADPT is a modular system for circular buildings, partnering with design startup Futur2k and Arup. The system is adaptable, flexible, scalable, reversible, and transportable, changing the way buildings are planned, realised, operated, and recycled at the end of their life cycle. The first prototype was shown off in Essen, Germany, in shapes of renewable and recyclable materials, which are now in use as residential or campus modules.

90980.title: Recofloor
90980.summary: Post-use vinyl flooring in new products
90980.problem: Previous recycling schemes only focused on own material and were unable to inform the supply chain
90980.solution: Two leading floor manufacturers combine to set up a takeback and reuse system for their in-use floor products
90980.outcome: After demonstrating that post-use materials were usable for new production, the project blossomed because of collaboration and bespoke designs
90980.additional_info: Recofloor and Axion in Hertfordshire have joined forces to create a post-use vinyl flooring recycling scheme that focuses on incorporating the materials into new products. This collaboration between two leading floor manufacturers has successfully set up a takeback and reuse system for their in-use floor products. By demonstrating the usability of post-use materials for new production and creating bespoke designs, the project has flourished, marking a significant shift from previous recycling schemes that only focused on their own material and were unable to inform the supply chain.

framework_elements.name: Team up to create joint value

90980.tags: Takeback programmes; flooring; recycling; collaboration; post-use materials

90990.title: Rainwater Harvesting and Greywater Recycling
90990.summary: Rainwater Harvesting and Greywater Recycling for all
90990.problem: Without proper rainwater and wastewater management, problems of scarcity and overrun may occur in cities
90990.solution: Aqua-Lity offer solutions for any project size, residential or the largest UK utility projects; Westfield shopping mall
90990.outcome: Aqua-Lity designs increase water recycling, rainwater absorption in the built environment and reduce waste water
90990.additional_info: Aqua-Lity in London offers solutions for rainwater harvesting and greywater recycling for all projects, from residential to the largest UK utility projects like Westfield shopping mall. Their designs increase water recycling, rainwater absorption in the built environment, and reduce waste water to prevent problems of scarcity and overrun in cities.
90990.tags: Water runoff; water recycling; rainwater harvesting; water management

91000.title: Bondedlogic Denim Insulation
91000.problem: Typical insulation materials require large energy inputs and use finite resources
91000.solution: Consists almost entirely of natural denim and cotton fibers that are 100% recyclable, reducing landfill waste. Contains 80% post-consumer recycled content.
91000.outcome: Aids the environment with energy conservation and reduction in pollution compared to other types of traditional insulation.
91000.additional_info: Bondedlogic Denim Insulation is a sustainable building material made from post-user denim waste. It consists almost entirely of natural denim and cotton fibers that are 100% recyclable, reducing landfill waste. With 80% post-consumer recycled content, this insulation aids in energy conservation and pollution reduction compared to traditional insulation materials. Contact Bondedlogic at 24053 S Arizona Ave Ste 151 Chandler, AZ 85248 to learn more about their environmentally friendly products.
91000.location: 24053 S Arizona Ave Ste 151 Chandler, AZ 85248

91010.title: Recycle Solar
91010.problem: First generation solar panels currently in use will become obsolete
91010.solution: Because of the high innovation rate in photovoltaics, panel providers are now creating a takeback scheme for first generation panels currently in use which will become obsolete in the coming years
91010.outcome: This initiative has focused on the creation of proper technology and strategies for PV recycling
91010.additional_info: Recycle Solar is anticipating the obsolescence of first generation solar panels currently in use. Panel providers are now creating a takeback scheme for these panels, focusing on proper technology and strategies for PV recycling. Visit recyclesolar.co.uk for more information. Located in London.
91010.tags: Solar panels; recycling; obsolescence; circular economy; takeback programme;
91010.source2: CBC_ List of case studies_Arup11.10.2023.xlsx - recyclesolar.co.uk

91020.title: The Promise of Glass in Concrete
91020.problem: Cement and concrete usage causes a substantial portion of global GHG emissions
91020.solution: Project goal: Can post-consumer glass be used as an additional substitute material in concrete?
91020.outcome: Glass in concrete would reduce carbon footprints, reduce toxic materials and find a much-needed use case for post-consumer glass
91020.additional_info: The Promise of Glass in Concrete: Avoiding cement usage and reducing global GHG emissions. Can post-consumer glass be used as a substitute material in concrete to reduce carbon footprints and toxic materials? This project aims to find a much-needed use case for post-consumer glass. Supported by EMF and Google in the USA.
91020.tags: Concrete; cement substituting; glass in concrete; post-consumer glass; carbon footprint

91030.title: Fit-out Alternatives
91030.problem: Utility buildings periodically fit-out replacable/degrading appliances and fixtures which is costly resource-wise
91030.solution: Three options are available to customers; purchase new furniture and return it in a buy-back scheme, purchase remade furniture from existing feedstock or have existing furnishings refreshed and returned to an as-new condition.
91030.outcome: Avoids the discarding of furniture and office fixtures
91030.additional_info:
Fit-out Alternatives: Changing office furnishing in France

Utility buildings periodically fit-out replaceable/degrading appliances and fixtures which is costly resource-wise. Three options are available to customers in France: purchase new furniture and return it in a buy-back scheme, purchase remade furniture from existing feedstock, or have existing furnishings refreshed and returned to an as-new condition. This approach avoids the discarding of furniture and office fixtures. Rype Office is leading the way in sustainable office furnishing solutions in France.
91030.tags: Fit-outs; takeback programmes; fit-out alternatives; avoiding waste

91040.title: Pasaporte de Materiales y activos sostenibles (P+MAS)
91040.summary: National technological passport for material data of real estate
91040.problem: The information gap in materials and products reuse
91040.solution: P+MAS is a technological platform at the national and Latin American level with the objective being disclosure of material passports of real estate assets
91040.outcome: Contributes to the development and implementation of whole life-cycle circularity models and helps circular building practices by providing material inventories
91040.additional_info: Pasaporte de Materiales y activos sostenibles (P+MAS) is a national technological platform that aims to disclose material passports of real estate assets in Chile and Latin America. This initiative, supported by Chile GBC and CTeC in Santiago, helps bridge the information gap in materials and products reuse. P+MAS contributes to the development and implementation of whole life-cycle circularity models, promoting circular building practices by providing material inventories.

framework_elements.name: Team up to create joint value

91040.tags: Materials passport; P+MAS; circularity modelling; MAS

91050.title: Delivering steel´s full reuse potential
91050.summary: Tool to maximise reclaimed steel usage in construction
91050.problem: Steel usage causes a substantial portion of global GHG emissions
91050.solution: Tool enables a project to achieve the optimum configuration for the replacement of new by reclaimed steel, and therefore the greatest carbon saving
91050.outcome: Helps overcome one of the main challenges for circularity in construction materials, the uncertainty, and a lack of documentation on their quality
91050.additional_info: Delivering steel´s full reuse potential: Tool to maximise reclaimed steel usage in construction. Steel usage causes a substantial portion of global GHG emissions. This tool enables a project to achieve the optimum configuration for the replacement of new by reclaimed steel, and therefore the greatest carbon saving. It helps overcome one of the main challenges for circularity in construction materials, the uncertainty, and a lack of documentation on their quality. Developed by WSP Global, Elephant and Castle Town Centre in London.
91050.organisation: WSP Global, Elephant and Castle Town Centre

framework_elements.name: Team up to create joint value

91050.tags: Steel; reuse potential; reclaimed steel; circularity modelling

91060.title: Light as a Service (LaaS)
91060.summary: Project works to save financially and reduce emissions by light being offered as a service in their tool
91060.problem: Upgrading old lighting is seen as an efficient and direct value project
91060.solution: The model enables customers to reduce installation and maintenance cost while significantly reducing CO2 emissions.
91060.outcome: Replacing older method light fixtures is a direct emissions saving measure
91060.additional_info: The Light as a Service (LaaS) project by C40 and Signify in Eindhoven works to save financially and reduce emissions by offering light as a service. Upgrading old lighting is seen as an efficient and direct value project, enabling customers to reduce installation and maintenance costs while significantly reducing CO2 emissions. Replacing older method light fixtures is a direct emissions saving measure.

91070.title: Circular Transition Indicator (CTI)
91070.summary: Quantitative framework measuring products AND processes including risk analysis
91070.problem: Aside from costs, the perceived risk of circular implementations can be a barrier to entry
91070.solution: Simple, unbiased, quantitative framework to measure circularity of business processes and products
91070.outcome: Helps companies evaluate risks, identify the most impactful actions to become more circular
91070.additional_info: Circular Transition Indicator (CTI) is a simple, unbiased quantitative framework developed by WBCSD in Geneva to measure the circularity of business processes and products. It includes risk analysis to help companies evaluate risks and identify the most impactful actions to become more circular. Aside from costs, the perceived risk of circular implementations can be a barrier to entry.
91070.tags: CTI; quantitative framework; circular economy; measuring circular business

91080.title: Buildings as Material Banks (BAMB)
91080.summary: International European project for Material Passports as a systemic shift
91080.problem: The information gap in materials and products reuse
91080.solution: An international initiative striving to provide better material inventories of many buildings throughout Europe
91080.outcome: Creating the largest library of material passports in the world can lead to massive gains in circularity and material reuse
91080.additional_info: Buildings as Material Banks (BAMB) is an international European project aiming to create Material Passports as a systemic shift in the information gap of materials and products reuse. This initiative strives to provide better material inventories for many buildings throughout Europe, with the goal of creating the largest library of material passports in the world. BAMB2020, which includes partners such as BRE and IBGE-BIM, is based in Brussels and aims to lead to massive gains in circularity and material reuse.
91080.tags: BAMB; material banks; materials passport; international European project

91090.title: Hong Kong sewage sludge treatment facility modelling
91090.summary: Using BIM much of the building process was virtualised and simplified
91090.problem: Modelling to speed up and improve sustainable building processes
91090.solution: BIM (Building Information Modelling) can help the  building process by
91090.outcome: BIM helped anticipate the material take-off and use throughout building lifespan
91090.additional_info: Arup in Hong Kong utilized BIM to virtualize and simplify the sewage sludge treatment facility modelling, speeding up and improving sustainable building processes. BIM helped anticipate material take-off and use throughout the building's lifespan.

91100.title: WikiHouse concept and WikiHouse 4.0
91100.summary: An open-source construction system that can be downloaded and used by anyone; enabling great customisation
91100.problem: The adaptability of current building paradigms is limited
91100.solution: Online building customisation platform, easy to learn but with depth
91100.outcome: Has been used to create WikiHouse 4.0 in London, with a variety of sustainable materials in use
91100.additional_info: The WikiHouse concept and WikiHouse 4.0, an open-source construction system developed by Arup in London, allows for great customization and adaptability in building design. This online platform enables easy learning and depth in customization, using a variety of sustainable materials for construction.

91110.title: Stadsloods
91110.summary: Tool to find vacant office space and book it, at a fee for the building owner
91110.problem: Vacancy and unuse in urban environment leads to losses on multiple fronts
91110.solution: Circular pavilion borrows from - and returns - materials to local suppliers
91110.outcome: Prevents the lack of use in active office buildings which need upkeep, also prevents vacancy in busy, sought-after areas
91110.additional_info: Stadsloods is a tool in Amsterdam that helps find vacant office space and book it for a fee, benefiting both the building owner and the local suppliers. This circular pavilion prevents losses from vacancy and unuse in urban environments by borrowing and returning materials to local suppliers. It also helps prevent the lack of use in active office buildings that need upkeep, as well as vacancy in busy, sought-after areas.

framework_elements.name: Team up to create joint value

91120.title: Structural Health Monitoring System (SHMS)
91120.summary: System using sensor data which provides safety and risk assessment for newly built structures
91120.solution: SHMS monitors structural health by sensory data, and is able to provide the foundation for complete risk assessments
91120.additional_info: Arup in London has developed a Structural Health Monitoring System (SHMS) that uses sensor data to monitor the health of newly built structures, providing safety and risk assessments. This system is able to provide a foundation for complete risk assessments by monitoring structural health through sensory data.

91130.title: Rehub.no
91130.summary: Online database and hub market for reusable and secondary materials, circular construction hub
91130.problem: The construction sector is projected to exceed its carbon budget by 2026 using current construction practices.
91130.solution: Hub for the further reselling of secondary material
91130.outcome: Locality of hub presents sustainable building options for nearby area while online marketplace will further spread sustainable methods
91130.additional_info: Rehub.no is an online database and hub market for reusable and secondary materials, with a focus on circular construction. The construction sector is projected to exceed its carbon budget by 2026 using current practices, making Rehub a crucial resource for sustainable building options. Located at Harbitzalléen 5, 0213 Oslo, Rehub serves as a hub for the reselling of secondary materials, offering a locality that presents sustainable building options for the nearby area. Additionally, the online marketplace provided by Rehub helps to further spread sustainable methods throughout the industry.

91130.source2: SOTA & Best Practices: State of the art knowledge and best circular practices

91140.title: Loopfront
91140.summary: Cloud-based platform for scanning material availability and recycling potential
91140.problem: Older buildings can contain useful materials but lack passports and/or circular principles to reveal these
91140.solution: Tool for building scans to reveal material availablity and providing estimates of reuse potential
91140.outcome: Offers online urban mining estimations with combined material availability; with the goal of easing process management of circular building
91140.additional_info: Loopfront is a cloud-based platform in Oslo that offers building scans to reveal material availability and estimates reuse potential. This tool is designed to help older buildings, which may lack passports or circular principles, uncover useful materials for recycling. By providing online urban mining estimations, Loopfront aims to streamline the process management of circular building projects.
91140.tags: Materials passport; material banks; impact scan; material scan; circularity potential
91140.source2: SOTA & Best Practices: State of the art knowledge and best circular practices

91150.title: Innovation Centre

91150.solution: Physical space and in-cloud collaboration on circular initiatives
91150.outcome: Fabrication laboratory and sharing space for circularity
91150.additional_info: Innovation Centre Platform and space in Barcelona, known as FABLAB Barcelona, to be used for piloting projects using circular principles. Facilitating circular pilots through physical space and in-cloud collaboration on circular initiatives, including a fabrication laboratory and sharing space for circularity.
91150.tags: Pilots; innovation; research centre; circular economy
91150.source2: SOTA & Best Practices: State of the art knowledge and best circular practices

91160.title: Madaster
91160.problem: Accessibility and easy of use of reuse materials
91160.solution: Large nation-wide database and marketplace of materials in various states of use
91160.outcome: Wider spread of circular building projects; better / easier options for reuse
91160.additional_info: Madaster is a digital library and marketplace for materials, providing accessibility and ease of use for reusing materials. 91170.title: Re-sign platform
91170.summary: Web tool for matching supply and demand for recycled building materials
91170.problem: Accessibility and easy of use of reuse materials
91170.solution: Due to the nature of hubs and reused materials supply and demand has too much effect on sales
91170.outcome: Wider spread of circular building projects; better / easier options for reuse
91170.additional_info: Re-sign.it is a web tool for matching supply and demand for recycled building materials in Varese. It aims to improve the accessibility and ease of use of reused materials, ultimately leading to a wider spread of circular building projects and better options for reuse. 91180.title: Automatic Embedded Product Inventories
91180.problem: Building decomission traditionally led to unused waste
91180.solution: Automatic embedded product inventories generated by BAM’s BIM software allows stakeholders to treat the constructions as a resource bank
91180.outcome: Enables the assets to be returned when a building is decommissioned
91180.additional_info: Automatic Embedded Product Inventories generated by BAM's BIM software in Bunnik allows stakeholders to treat constructions as a resource bank, enabling assets to be returned when a building is decommissioned, reducing unused waste traditionally associated with decommissioning.
